metadata.case_name: Radhakishan Jaikishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa

facts.text: In July 1922, the Municipal Committee, Khandwa, resolved to impose a tax on the trade of ginning and pressing cotton by means of steam or mechanical process.
Notification No. 2639-1298-VIII dated November 21, 1922 published on November 25, 1922 in the Central Provinces and Berar Gazette, imposing the tax.
Municipal Committee served notices on appellant and demanded and recovered tax for 1923-24.
Traders including appellant filed suits seeking injunction against Municipal Committee on ground tax invalid and illegal.
Appellant filed second suit for refund of tax paid, on ground imposition illegal and ultra vires.
Privy Council first decision remitted cases for additional evidence: Radhakrishan Jaikishan v. Khandwa Municipal Committee (1933 LR 61 IA 125).
After additional evidence, Privy Council held tax not validly imposed, reversed Judicial Commissioner, decreed suits: Badhakishan Jaikishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa (1937 LR 64 IA 118).

Khandwa Ginning and Pressing Cotton Tax Validating Act 8 of 1938 passed by Provincial Legislature, validating tax from date of imposition to date Act comes into force; Explanation deemed decrees/orders for refund/restraining recovery ineffective.

Appellant applied for execution of decrees; Validating Act pleaded in bar, upheld by executing court, rejected by Nagpur High Court on appeal: Firm Radhakishan v. Municipal Committee, Khandwa (1940 NLJ 638); reason: Explanation conflicted with O.45 R.15 CPC, no assent of Governor-General under s.107 GOI Act 1935.

Provincial Legislature dissolved, Governor assumed powers under s.93 GOI Act 1935; enacted Khandwa Municipality Validation of Tax Act, 1941 (16 of 1941), assented June 30, 1941, published July 11, 1941; validated tax from Nov 21, 1922 to March 31, 1938; provisions for recovery of balance, net sum recovered defined, execution of decrees not precluded but tax recoverable.
Provincial Government framed rule for recovery by execution application to court that executed decree.
Municipal Committee deposited decretal amount in court, withdrawn by appellant on furnishing security.
On August 7, 1947, Municipal Committee filed application under rule for execution; appellant objections raised but disallowed; tax realised from surety.
Appellant appealed to Nagpur High Court on Nov 16, 1949; Mudholkar J held 1941 Act ultra vires s.142A; Sinha CJ and Deo J disagreed, appeal dismissed.
Certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 Constitution obtained; appeal filed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Khandwa Municipality Validation of Tax Act, 1941 (passed by Governor under s.93 GOI Act 1935) was ultra vires due to repugnancy with s.142A GOI Act 1935, which limited taxes on professions etc. to Rs.50 per annum after March 31, 1939.
Whether s.142A prohibited retrospective validating legislation for tax imposition prior to March 31, 1939.

petitioner_arguments.text: The 1941 Validating Act ultra vires Provincial Legislature/Governor, repugnant to s.142A GOI Act 1935 imposing Rs.50 limit on taxes on professions after March 31, 1939; Act passed after that date exceeded limit.

respondent_arguments.text: 1941 Act valid; retrospective and validating laws within plenary powers of Provincial Legislature/Governor; s.142A does not prohibit validation for period before March 31, 1939.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Government of India Act, 1935 ss.93, 107; Provincial Legislative List Entry 46

court_reasoning.text: Powers of Provincial Legislatures plenary, include retrospective and validating laws; no prohibition against retrospective legislation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislatures not subject to unusual prohibition against retrospective laws.

court_reasoning.text: Validating Acts can render inoperative court decrees/orders; power ancillary to legislative entries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Examples upheld by Federal Court and Supreme Court.

court_reasoning.text: s.142A(1) validates provincial taxes on professions not as income tax; s.142A(3) preserves federal income tax entry; s.142A(2) limits taxes to Rs.50 after March 31, 1939, but proviso allows existing higher rates; no limit or prohibition for prior period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1941 Act validates tax up to March 31, 1938, before dateline; prohibition confined to period after March 31, 1939.

court_reasoning.text: 1941 Act within powers, removes defect in 1938 Act retrospectively; complies with formalities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Does not fall within ban of s.142A(2); no need for proviso support.

holdings.text: Khandwa Municipality Validation of Tax Act, 1941 valid and within powers of Governor.
s.142A does not prohibit retrospective validation of tax for period prior to March 31, 1939.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding the 1941 Validating Act intra vires and valid, upholding the High Court's dismissal of the appellant's appeal against execution and recovery of tax.

key_quotes.text: "the burden of proving that Indian Legislatures were subject to a strange and unusual prohibition against retrospective legislation lay upon those who asserted it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms plenary power for retrospective laws

key_quotes.text: "The total amount payable in respect of any one person... shall not, after the thirty-first day of March nineteen hundred and thirty-nine, exceed fifty rupees per annum."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.142A(2); limits apply only post March 31, 1939

key_quotes.text: "The Validating Act, though passed in 1941, can be read only as affecting a period for which there was no limit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on why 1941 Act valid
